html.p: What: Efficiently "augments" existing data with information from a CSV.

ol.li: Can be made to function automatically.
Vastly more efficient than variations with append

html.p: How: lookup <lookup name> <lookup field> AS <matching field in data> OUTPUT/OUTPUTNEW <field in lookup> AS <new name for field from lookup> <maybe another field from lookup> AS <and a new name for it>
Why: Extremely efficient at adding in relatively small (e.g. not TB!) set of reasonably static data.
So What: Commonly used to do things like convert status codes into status strings. Instead of "404" you could build a new field that said "Not Found".
We're using data we built earlier by using outputlookup. To build this see outputlookup
You'll see what this looks like in the first data pane below.
And also a new lookup created with outputlookup -
html.pre: | makeresults format=csv data="count, outcome 0,Fired 1,Warned 2,\"OK, I guess\" 3,OK 4,Good 5,\"Bonus!\"" | outputlookup rdf_sales_outcomes.csv

panel.title: Original Data
panel.html: Note this is just the contents of the lookup that we built ages ago.

panel.title: Data with lookup
panel.html: By adding | lookup rdf_sales_outcomes.csv count AS cars OUTPUT outcome as Outcome" to the end, look what happens!

search.query: | inputlookup rdf_cars.csv | lookup rdf_sales_outcomes.csv count AS cars OUTPUT outcome as Outcome

panel.html: Note - normally you would use this command against lookups that were defined via the UI (or in .conf files). By doing it the way we're doing it, we have to specify the CSV file exactly (including the ".csv" at the end), otherwise it works just the same. Except of course we can make these "automatic". To do that, see the fine docs on lookups.
